column1: == History ==

India experienced a phenomenal rate of urban growth during the 25 years following independence and Bombay has had its due share in it. The population of Greater Bombay rose from 2.966 million in 1951 to 4.152 million in 1961 and to 5.970 million in 1971
column2: registering 40.0 and 43.80 percent growths during the first and second decades respectively. The rapid rate of growth of population
column3: made possible by the increasing industrial and commercial importance of the city
column4: resulted in a fast deterioration in the quality of life for the majority of people living in the city. Development inputs could not keep pace with the rapidly growing population
column5: industry
column6: trade and commerce. Besides
column7: there are physical limitations to the growth of a city built on a long and narrow peninsula
column8: which has very few connections with the mainland.

column1: The Government of Maharashtra has been alive to the emerging problems of this metropolis. Responsible public opinion was equally vigilant and several constructive suggestions appeared from time to time in the press and elsewhere. All this helped in keeping the problems of Bombay in the forefront of public awareness. In 1958
column2: the Govt. of Bombay appointed a study group under the Chairmanship of Shri S.G. Barve
column3: Secretary to Government
column5: to consider the problems relating to congestion of traffic
column6: deficiency of open spaces and playfields
column7: shortage of housing and over-concentration of industry in the metropolitan and suburban areas of Bombay
column8: and to recommend specific measures to deal with these.

column1: The Barve Group reported in February 1959. One of its major recommendations was that a rail-cum-road bridge is built across the Thane Creek to connect peninsular Bombay with the mainland. The group felt that the bridge would accelerate development across the Creek
column2: relieve pressure on the city's railways and roadways
column3: and draw away industrial and residential concentrations eastward to the mainland. The Group hoped that the eastward development would be orderly and would take place in a planned manner.
